text: When I was writing my book "I Need an Exorcism" I read Paul O'Gradys books, At My Mothers Knee, The Devil Rides Out and Still Standing. Now I re-read his books if I need to cheer myself up. I have read them a few times now. Struggling with my book I even pretended I was telling Paul a story to get me to write better. Much of my humour in my book I've managed as a result of reading Paul's books. I am the same age as Paul so it was very interesting to compare where I was at in my life when he was describing his life. His life was a lot more interesting than mine. And the Elephant and Castle, pub, I heard the Peter Skellern song about it years ago but I couldn't make out the words so I didn't know exactly how rough the pub was until I read Pauls books. And the opening to Still Standing, his description of a Leeds pub, well, it's beyond belief the brewery allows that pub to be open. Makes my local look very tame in comparison. For those of a somewhat nervous disposition, like myself, I can safely say that reading these books will be an education in themselves and make anyones problems look smaller in comparison. I will always re-read these books. Love 'em.

I would love to give this 10 stars if possible. In parts laugh-out-loud funny but also at times very poignant, this is a marvellous evocation of a Catholic working class upbringing in the 1950s through to the mid-70s. Highly recommended.

This is one of my favourite autobiographies. I have been a fan of Paul O'Grady for a long time, I think he's fantastic and funny without even trying to be. I loved his teatime show on Channel 4. This book chronicles his life up until (I think) he is 18 and is very funny. I am from Liverpool so recognised the places he was talking about from my side of the water, but not the places he wrote about from his side. But that didn't matter. It was fantastic reading about Paul's life growing up and what he got up to as a child and then a teenager, he certainly had an eventful life up until he was 18. And even after that his life became even more eventful.Definitely not a book to miss for O'Grady fans.

Now I like Paul O'Grady, I really do but... This was so boring! He tells it as it was, rather than in his TV voice - and I like the TV voice so it just didn't make me want to carry on. Got about half way through.

Totally hilarious, couldn't put it down.."It was Brother Kearney who gave my mother her favourite quote about me. He was the one who said 'born to trouble as sparks fly upwards'. 'Job, chapter five, verse seven,' my mother had replied, completely knocking the wind out of his sails."

I'm a mega huge O'Grady fan, I love this man, his devotion to animals is just amazing, He can do no wrong in my eyes, this is a funny, sad and comical book, telling the story of Paul's early life in Birkenhead.

I loved this book. It was heartwarming, funny, sometimes sad but above all, brutally honest.I laughed out loud at Paul's shenanigans and I cried at the end. This is hands down the best autobiography I have read to date.
Who would have thought such a man could make me cry reading this!! Emotional, funny , raw and full of life!
What a read, I absolutely loved it and to see how hard it was growing up back in the 60's and 70's and being gay was so hard and it wasn't acceptable like nowadays

Read this on bit of a Whim and found it utterly engrossing, I was never a particular fan of Lilly Savage or Paul O'Grady, but he is a fantastic writer. Other autobiography writers should take note, his stories are interesting but despite being written by the protagonist himself, I never felt anything was played down or over dramatized, and that he simply wrote about his experiences growing up without any prejudice or spin on his part.Looking forward to reading the next installment of his life.

I found this to be an entertaining read, I knew he had a colourful background he is frank and honest and you can see where Lily came from, his family is interesting,the women are strong, powerful and compassionate stubborn creatures who are every bit as colourful as our Paul, the men hold a prehapes quieter place, but are none the less as inportant, it was interesting reading about his feelings and confusion about his sexuality,a recommend but possibly for fans only - cant wait for the sequel!

I enjoyed quite a bit of this book. I found it interesting to find out about life in Birkenhead for Paul O'Grady, as it's an area I know. There were some funny stories, which were entertaining. There was also some sad moments. There were some good observations from his own memories which were good. The book showed the ups and downs of life. There were some bits that were a bit slow at times. Reading about someone's early life makes you look at them differently.

Likeable and occasionally entertaining though Mr O'Grady might be - this book is certainly not 'hilarious' and ultimately just...pointless. (I only read it whilst a member of a reading group - the premise of the group being that members were encouraged to read books they might ordinarily never consider reading - thanks reading group!).

Wow.I mean no disrespect to Paul O'grady but this is what I imagine Jeffrey Archer aims for in his works of fictions and keeps failing at it.Maybe Paul's secret ingredient is that the people in this are all real.

I absolutely loved it! I can't believe that by the end of the book he's only just reached the age of 18 and not yet got into show business. It's completely absorbing, hilarious and vividly written. I can't wait for the next installment of his life!

I've always liked Paul O'Grady, he's very funny and also seems to be a genuinely nice guy. I enjoyed this first instalment of his life story, it's written in an almost conversational, rambling style with the author going off at lots of interesting tangents.
[Short review from memory until I re-read and re-review at a later date:No memory really, but I assume quite amusing if not enlightening. Just your average autobiography, I think.]
Eat you heart out Peter Kay.
A very enjoyable read, looking forward to reading the others.
A great fun read, well written and personal. A lovely account of Paul's early life.
3.5 I enjoyed learning about Paul's past and life in Liverpool and the many characters in his family. Got this book at a charity shop second hand.

Exploring his family background and his early years in Liverpool. Amusing and slightly shocking in places but you can hear him narrating all the way through. You can see where he got his inspiration for Lilly Savage from.

What a warm lovey funny book. Absolutely love Paul O‚ÄôGrady and this just sealed the deal. Such an evocative postcard from the past. It‚Äôs a relief to hear it wast just us who used to have to pop some money in the meter to keep it going, I can‚Äôt imagine living in a house with no inside loo. You read this book thinking how can that be a thing that happened in living memory.I love him, love his family especially al the outspoken no nonsense women. So many of them to base Lilly Savage on.And it‚Äôs also a really important book about being gay in the 70s and 80s. The olden days (I can‚Äôt believe I just said that) I can‚Äôt wait to read all his other books now because that was really fun
Laugh out loud, but such a sad ending. Tissues at the ready. Can‚Äôt wait for the next instalment now.

The title caught my eye because it was something my mum always used to say: "I learned it at my mother's knee--or some other low joint." I really enjoyed Paul's chat show, and admire what he has done to encourage pet adoptions. Having read Paul O'grady: The Biography (typical British-written "authorised biography" stuff, style and all) I was interested to see what he had to say for himself.The tone is certainly different, as is the emphasis. I had expected a bit more elaboration of family dynamics etc, but what we get is mostly his explorations of his own sexuality, and from a very young age (confirming what me aged mum always told me, that "it's all boys think about" *sarcasm*). I had expected a bit more of a humourous tone than there is, or maybe it's me? Maybe the humour is scripted into the shows, and not natural to the man.I am no prude, and certainly no stranger to books like Hiding My Candy, but...this book disappointed me rather. Not that I was looking for scabrous tales of abuse and neglect, indeed--for that we have Chablis' book. But I don't know...I expected something different. Aside from his sexcapades, a lot of it is pretty surface. We are told he has a couple of siblings, but that's all; not much interaction.Will I read the other two volumes of this memoir? Remains to be seen. I've had a dip into Still Standing: The Savage Years and it seems to be more of same.

As a scouser myself, I really enjoyed this book being familiar with all the places he writes about is obviously helpful, but even so Paul paints the pictures with his words very well.This cover's his early years ending when his is in his 18th year, he does not hide or candy coats his experiences which I believe says a lot about his character, it could have been all to easy to show himself in a better light, but this shows him for the "scally" (scouse term for trouble maker) he really was.People who do not understand the "Scouse" sense of humour might find what he writes a little harsh and uncaring, but in actual fact this is just honest understatment of what were very harsh and unyeilding times and the comments are in my opinion his way on making light of very hard times and situations.Not an easy book to read, but nontherless enjoyable in its own way and show's a light on a period of the early 1960's when everyone thinks was such a good time, when in fact like now, there are hard and painfull issues we all have to face.

It was a good book, a bit long and uninteresting sometimes, but generally a decent read. I can't say that I'd recommend it to everyone though, his sense of humor definitely demands a certain type of person (If your not British and used to the British sense of humor, no offense guys but it is different from the American sense of humor)I did have a few favorite stories, dont worry I wont go into details, just suffice to say, some Americans can get the humor yay! lol.All in all, though back to the review, a good overall read. No one part to really pick at, just some bits took me awhile to get interested in, but that is the way with someones life. I don't care who you are, if you are telling someone your life story at some part that you think is vital, someone is going to yawn!

With an acid-tongue and a heart of gold, Paul O'Grady's tale of his childhood in Birkenhead outside Liverpool is both hilarious and heartbreaking with a bit of Dickensian squalor and pathos thrown in for good measure. Even though Paul and I are the same age, his childhood couldn't have been any different than mine if he'd grown up on a different planet! Still, the practice of looking at tragedy and struggle with a quip and a smile or a laugh is one I grew up with too so in some ways, I understand his family. Surprisingly straight-laced at times, Paul still manages to end up in some "low joints" and with some real characters. It makes fascinating reading and is told with such honesty and truth you know he's holding nothing back. Very enjoyable but boy, am I glad I grew up in the US!

Loved this book!! Love Lily Savage!! Didn't know much about the man behind her but I now love Paul O'Grady too!! Honest and candid, it felt like I grew up beside him. As if he was part of my family. Some of his antics had me giggling to myself and others had me rolling around the floor in stitches. He even made me cry!! A highly recommendable book for anyone who's a fan. Only set back was I was hungry for more...and that's when I learned there was a second book...and after that one, a third! Very clever on your part, Mr O'Grady!
brilliant and a sad all at the same time.

Paul tells the story of his early upbringing in working class Liverpool with superb detail, emotion and good humour. He recalls the colourful characters of his family and friends with great affection. He tells how, during his teen years he was curious abuut both men and women, and not being afraid to experiment. The book ends in his eighteenth year when his life is changed forever, and leaves you eager to read his next installment.

Loved the first half of this book, it was so witty and had me laughing out loud on many occassions. I especially loved how he described his Mum and the things she used to do. Towards the end I found it lost it's humour and began to be more about his going out onto the gay scene. I thought he should have stopped writing around chapter 15. Still, I reccomend this as a great read, something easy, perfect for holiday.

I've rewritten this, because when I wrote it originally, I had only read half the book, and upto that point it was really shit, but when he stopped writing about his mother, after half way through, it finally got interesting, and started talking about him, and his life growing up etc. hope we see another book, after his later life etc, that would be more interesting. i've changed my score from a 1 star to 3 stars.

I found it lying around at my parents' place and didn't expect much, but Mr O'Grady is an engagingly sympathetic character, so I kept with him as he stumbled through his pious Catholic upbringing, between boyfriends and girlfriends, consistently disappointing and disgusting his parents and their relatives. It's a good read, particularly if you like the word "peripatetic" or have no desire of a Polari glossary for when he lands in London.

Not a particular fan of PG but remembered a reviewer saying he hadn't expected to enjoy it but had loved it. I have a deep suspicion of celebrities turned writers (Ben Elton, Stephen Fry) but Alexei Sayle wrote some very funny and impressive books. Fortunately I enjoyed this. It made me laugh and cry and took me back to my childhood when I lived in Birkenhead for a couple years. Great way to end the book too!

The man on TV with all the dogs from Battersea dogs home. Who would have thought! after leaving a ship in Liverpool dock after another orgy would "walk the length of the dock to a chorus of catcalls and wolf whistles from the Dockers. Fuck 'em. Instead of running, head down, for the hole in the fence I was sashaying, head and two fingers up, out of the front gate".A look at the early life and sexual life up to aged 18 (and no sign yet of Lily Savage)of Paul O'Grady

Really enjoyed this book as he captured Britain in the sixties and seventies so well. He has great ear for dialogue, and you can hear the conversations in your head.Many funny lines, and all in all makes you realise that he's a whole lot sharper than the entertainer that you see on telly. Fab light read and I can't wait for the the follow up!

Paul O'Grady first came to national attention as the foul-mouthed tart with a heart of gold, Lily Savage. In these very well-written memoirs we never actually see the birth of Lily and her rise to fame, but instead the focus is on Paul's first 20-odd years and his very modest background.I look forward to a second volume to cover his adult life.

Paul O'Grady (aka Lily Savage) gives us an honest, down-to-earth account of his early (up to age18) life in working class Birkenhead. You don't have to be one of his fans ton enjoy this book, which is so engaging, perceptive, sad and funny all in one volume that I have downloaded volume 2 (The Devil Rides Out) and cannot wait to read it.

I do really like this book, and it was a good read, I did find that in some parts you had to put a bit of effort into reading it but it was worth it. It was funny in parts but also serious in others. Also, the part where he was giving his mother dope: Hilarious!!I think he describes his mother well, his second auto-biography has just come out, hopefully buying that soon

I'm no great fan of the latter day incarnation of Paul O'Grady but there is much to like about this book. What is most rivetting is Paul's unflinching honesty about his own flaws or less than honourable episodes of his life and it infuses the whole book with a openness and warmth. If you like (auto)biographies, put this one on your "to-read" list.

Completely and unexpected enjoyed this book. Through out you have Mr O'Grady's voice retelling his formative years in an honest, forthright and sometime hillarious manner. There are definately some laugh out louds moments as well as some that cause a large lump to form in the throat. Well written, entertaining and throughly readable

Loved this book, honest, humorous, great tales of Birkenhead. I am not generally an autobiography reader but there are some people that I believe are interesting enough to divulge a few hours too! Paul writes honestly and not about stardom but about growing up in general. Hilarious tales of cabaret clubs and queens. Well worth reading.

I loved this book - it provided a fascinating insight into Paul O'Gradys early life and family history. There were times when I laughed out loud, times when I felt sad and not a moment when I was ever bored.I can't wait to read his next book to continue the journey - it has definitely increased my liking for this man!

An hilarious story of this comedians life and one that I related to so well. Living in a street full of 'aunties' who helped to bring you usually with a clip round the back of the head with the advice "that was for what you haven't done yet". I took this book on holiday with me and finished it poolside within 2 days. Brilliant,

I absolutely adored this book, it had everything a good autobiography should have. It made me laugh, it made me cry and it made me think about how hard it must have been for Paul growing up. Loved it.

I love Paul O'grady as an entertainer and off course, his portrayal of Lily Savage. I found his autobiography to be very endearing, honest, and Paul to be witty and full of warmth especially towards his long suffering family, mainly his parents. An essential read if you like this man!

An ok book, however did seem to go into a bit to much at places, no one needs to know so much about his life, every little detail is recorded and that get's a little annoying.If you want to know more about Paul, read, however if you want a quick fame book, don't.

I love Paul O'Grady. And speaking as a fellow Birkonian of his, I can highly recommend this book as one of the most enjoyable and entertaining showbiz biographies I have ever read. If you are a fan of Paul O'Grady, then I guarantee you will enjoy every page of this book.

A 'must' read if you're a catholic who grew up around Birkenhead during the '50s, '60s or 70s ( like myself). However, as biographies go it wasn't my favourite. ( Graham Norton is). But an enjoyable read all in all.

I love Paul O'Grady and his story wasn't disappointing. A natural storyteller. I actually laughed out loud in places which is very rare. He has such a natural style you come to see him as a friend. The end is a real cliff-hanger for the next installment

I'm not a fan but liked the look of this as I do enjoy memoirs. I loved the stories about his Mum, Dad and Aunties, but stopped enjoying it when it got onto his school days. I might have enjoyed more if it had been an audiobook though.

I loved it. It was very readable, and I had a hard time putting it down. I've only seen the author as a guest on Graham Norton's show, so I'm totally unfamiliar with his work. That didn't lessen my pleasure with the book in the least. I would gladly read more by Paul O'Grady.

Who'd have thought that Paul was such a scally in his youth.Very interesting book, so much so my wife bought me the second part of his autibiography "The Devil Rides Out" to follow up as a Christmas present.

I haven't watched any of his TV stuff but as a writer, Paul O'Grady is immensely readable and can bring the characters from his childhood to life in a way that allows you to be there next to him as he recalls the anecdotes of family life in Birkenhead as he was growing up. I enjoyed the book a lot.

Not really the kind of thing I usually read. A few amusing moments, but a struggle to stay with it to the end, and then disappointed that it did not go far enough to tell how Paul got into show business.

I loved this book,he`s such a likeable character,and all the old stories of Liverpool really made me laugh.He only mentions Lily Savage once though,very fleetingly,i soon found out by the abrupt ending that you have to buy his other books to read about Lily,which really annoyed me.
Paul O'Grady. At my Mothers Knee and other low joints I like Paul. enjoyed his first book, but this one, does not ring true. tells a different story, cannot believe all between 16 to 17

What a good read. Paul o'grady lays all bear it's a no holds barred read. You get to know the childhood that shaped the man. And the influences of his extended family. As you read it you can't help but hear Paul o'gradys voice. A great read.

Unfortunately I couldn't finish this book. I love Paul O'grady and all the work he does and has done but I couldn't read this book. I found myself bored whenever I picked it up. I tried to read as much as I could in the hope it would pick up but it didn't so in the end I had to give up reading it.

Great StoryWhat a great story of the young Paul O'Grady growing up and the trials and troubles he put his parents through Of him trying to come to terms with his sexual orientation in a very difficult time Would definitely recommend
absolutly hilarious.......cant wait until the next instalment
Often hilarious, sometimes tragic story of O'Grady's early years. Appears to have been genuinely written by him and not ghosted as his voice and humour come over clearly.
I really loved this book. It seems a very honest account of this very funny mans life.I would definately read more from this man.I found myself laughing out loud on many occasions..
I absolutely loved this book , laughed out loud at times and can not wait for the next installment.
Very funny. Great book to read. Highly recommended.
Pauls a hoot. Written as if he was talking to you, Lily Savage n'all.
A sometimes hilarious account of Paul O'Grady's upbringing and escapades. It was easy to see how his experiences made him the person that is loved by TV viewers.
I can't stop laughing, this book explains so much about this interesting gentleman.
Did not like this at all. I thought it would tell me about his whole life. I did not like him much before reading this and I like him less now
I can relate to some of his comments like "She knew instinctively what to do with the delicate cuttings that she nicked on her many excursions to the stately homes of England", LOL thats my mum too.
I simply loved this. His writing voice is so endearing, and he writes with real compassion. I couldn't put this book down, and the sequel couldn't come quick enough!
Laughed my face off. A great read for anyone who enjoys a lively, witty, painfully truthful memoir.
Enjoyed this book but felt it got too detailed at some times and sort of lost interest. Loved the way he described his family so vividly. Have to say he seemed to have a hedonistic youth!
so far funny can hear his voice and see his facial expressionstakes us through his teens when he didn't know where he was going
Loved this book. Very Paul and very honest. I can't believe it ended where it did! I hope that his second biography picks up where this one left off.
An entertaining read (even if you're not familiar with O'Grady).Is there going to be another instalment?? (it only goes upto the age of 18)I'll be reading it if/when it is published!
Sooo funny, he's such a normal down to earth bloke! Has to be a follow on though with an ending like that!
excellent read, was slightly disappointed that it ended before he found fame and fortune but I am hoping he is planning the next stage!
Brilliant book really funny.
I was expecting this to be good and it wasn't I thought it would of been funny but only bits were.
This was much better than I thought it would be.I shall buy the rest of his books.
What a great book. Only Paul himself could have told it like that. A giggle a minute but does have it's serious parts. loved it.
It was OK, entertaining but nowhere near as funny as I was expecting.
Laughed and cried all the way through
Really good book about his background,lots of funny bits in it.
read few pages n couldnt get into it as didnt understand somethings
Enjoyed this quite a bit. A very interesting read.Am passing on to my mum as I think she'll like it too.
loved reading about Paul's early life and what influenced him. as you read, you can imagine him next to you telling the story in his own unique way.
Have never laughed so much at a book for a long time. Another great read from this funny guy.
Entertaining and well written.
Really enjoyed this, so much so that I downloaded the sequel immediately. Very good natural voice, even in pure liverpudlian.
Funny, moving, open and honest Paul O' Grady started from humble beginnings and has gone on to become one of Britains well loved characters x
loved the way it was written, felt like paul was in the room reading it to you
a book where you can hear Paul's voice throughout, a fascinating insight into his early life and also the birkenhead and Liverpool of the 1960's and 70's
A brilliant autobiography - Paul's life-story is so believable yet at the same time almost beyond belief!
Thoroughly enjoyed this book. Paul O'Grady writes with such warmth of his childhood and adolescence in Birkenhead, with many laugh out loud moments. Looking forward to volume two.
I don't usually like biographies but his one made me laugh - I am looking forward the reading his two other books.
I found this book very funny and couldn't put it down until I'd finished reading it
Absolutely fantastic book- really humble, and with an unexpected ending.
Entertaining and enlightening!
I learnt a few surprising things about Paul in the book - his career as a social worker in London, being just one. An easy, flowing read which I chose between heavier books - glad I did!
a good insight to his early life x
I thoroughly enjoyed this book and will definitely read his other autobiographies that are out now.
A thoroughly enjoyable read, made better because you can almost hear his voice as you're reading. Bring on part two: 'The Devil Rides Out.'
Not sure when I finished this, but guessing 2009
Paul O'Grady is not only funny but has quite a shocking and vivid life. Laughed out loud at some of his stories and sat with mouth wide open on others. A very funny read.
Funny, genuine, full of heart. Quite extraordinary that this was just 60 years ago, the world he describes seems so far removed from Modern Britain.
Really funny, hilarious characters and I can't wait to read the next one!
Good fun and lots of information about his early life. We are left with a cliffhanger! Hopefully this means Book Two...
Love Paul O Grady and loved this book
Paul's early life, with tongue-in-cheek good humour, if a bit long and rambling in places
Fantastic book especially for me as i'm a huge Paul O'Grady fan and i have to admit i've read this book twice already
Laughed all the way through
I really wanted to find this brilliant, as I think Paul O Grady is but I didn't, shame .
So funny , couldn‚Äôt stop laughing. Easy read aswell couldnt put it down
This was a fabulous book laughing till the tears ran down my face and doing the same with the sad bits just a great run
MarvellousWitty, funny, emotional and poignant. A great read and highly recommended. Will look for next volume and report back .
I can't say that before I read this book I was a fan of Paul, but a friend gave it to me , and I found I really did warm to him. It was, in my opinion, a good read
i enjoyed this book a lot funny and well written you feel as if you really know about the characters mentioned in the book
A friend was reading this on holiday and he kept laughing out loud. I thought I'd give it a go and whilst it was amusing, unfortunately l never laughed out loud like my friend.
I absolutely love Paul O' Grady, I used to watch his chat show and the love of dogs, and of course his game shows. Can't wait to read the next one when he gets to his more showbiz life.
A very good book, worth reading
Brilliant I have laughed and cried throughout reading this book. I have loved it as well, he has a lovely way of writing as if he is having a conversation with you.

If I am being honest, which I am, I rarely don't read books twice. I have only read a handful of books twice. This book is one of those books. I don't why, but I find Paul's life fascinating. Like me he is an animal lover.Paul takes the reader through his first eighteen years of his life, from his birth in 1955 to his dad's passing in 1973. Giving the reader an insight into how his family ended up in Birkenhead. Born on the 14th June 1955 in St Catherine's Hospital in Tranmere, his father Patrick Grady was born in Ireland, moved to England in 1936. His surname was changed by mistake to O'Grady when he joined the RAF and he kept it. He married Mary Savage (1916-88) who was born in England to Irish immigrants. Both were devout Catholics and raised their children in the faith. Paul was their third child, Sheila born in 1941 and Brendan in 1944, he was unplanned, his mother finding out about the pregnancy after visiting the doctor complaining about indigestion. Paul spent his early life at 23 Holly Grove in Higher Tranmere. Attending St Joseph's Catholic Primary School, he excelled in everything except Mathematics. His parents sent him to Redcourt, where his grades dropped. Failing his eleven plus, he couldn't go to a grammar school so was sent to the Blessed Edmund Campion Secondary Modern and the Corpus Christi High School. A fan of the Avengers and Batman, he joined the cub scouts, leaving after a month. An altar boy at a Catholic Church, he was dismissed after laughing during a funeral service. He then joined the Marine Cadets, later commenting that he was following in the footsteps of his first hero, Popeye. Enjoying the cadets, he joined the Boys Amateur Boxing Club, leading to a lifelong love of the sport. His first job was a paper round that lasted the week. Leaving school aged 16, he obtained a job in the DHSS as a clerical assistant at the Liverpool office. He also worked part time in the bar at the RAFA club in Oxton. Resigning from the DHSS, he managed to obtain a job at the Wheatsheaf Hotel in Virginia Water in Surrey. Appalled at the working conditions, the management accused him of stealing, which he denied. Returning to Birkenhead, he returned to the RAFA club, increasingly socialising with within the Liverpudlian gay scene, attending meetings of the CHE and working at the Bear's Paw, a gay bar. This he kept a secret from his parents. With best friend, Tony, he regularly travelled to London to socialise with Tony's friend, John Pritchard, the classical music conductor, becoming very fond of him. Experimenting, he had sex with friend Diane. The book ends with Paul working at Liverpool Magistrates Court, finding out that Diane is pregnant in the same week as his parents have heart attacks, after having returned from a holiday, his mother later recovering but his father passing away.

I just didn't enjoy this book very much, I thought I'd love it as I think Paul on the television is very funny but I found it underwhelming which I was disappointed by as the reviews for this book are on the whole very positive. The book focuses purely on his life from Birth to around the age of 18 and Paul's voice shines through in the writing, you can't help but read the book in his voice.I've tried to pinpoint why I didn't enjoy this book very much and I don't think it was one singular reason, more a culmination of things making it underwhelming. Firstly I never felt as though the reader got to know Paul, the first third of the book is focused on his family history and detailed description of each of his family members which was interesting but I kept wondering when Paul was going to talk about himself and his memories. He did move on to his anecdotes but they stayed heavily rooted in his surrounding family and tended to focus on their reactions and feelings to things he had done rather than focusing on himself. He rarely wrote about his own emotions and feelings but when he did so such as on the death of his Father he wrote beautifully with emotion. It showed a softer side to him compared to the one portrayed throughout the rest of the book. Secondly, there wasn't much of Paul's trademark wit in this book, there were funny moments but most of the humour came from the anecdotes featuring Paul's Mother Molly. Additionally there were a few early anecdotes which I found quite upsetting involving animal cruelty (not involving Paul himself) and I really didn't like them. Paul on the television comes across as really likeable but the Paul in this book doesn't, a lot of his actions are self-centred, potentially this is due to the book only covering his early years and most likely he matures as the books progress as there were signs of it towards the end of this book. I had already bought the next book before I had read this one so I will be reading that soon. I'm not sure i'd recommend this book, but many other people have so maybe give it a try for yourself.

I couldn‚Äôt put this book down as it was such a good read. I have always enjoyed watching Paul O‚ÄôGrady on television not so much as Lily Savage but certainly in all his other programmes and also on radio. He is so good at presenting and entertainment and is very funny.This autobiography is one of a few that he has written and this one covers his early life etc. I related very much to what he described as he is the same age as me and growing up in the 60‚Äôs is accurately described by him and it brought many memories back to me too if that period. He is very honest too of how his relationships with his parents were and it also has a lot of humour too in that. He is very open on how he matured into adolescence and teenage years and of his experiences with both females and males. He describes the conversations with his mother and aunties etc and I could clearly hear them as I read the book and their accents and mannerisms came across clearly to me. The 1960‚Äôs was a progressive time for us to grow up in and Paul describes that so well. His whole time of trying to find his feet in work is accurate and clear are his times of where things just go wrong for him and the words of his mother and father echoing to me in that same way......it made me smile......he turned out doing well for himself....and so did I.....life is like that.....so it shapes us and makes us what we are. I recommend reading this book.....and it has made me want to read more of his autobiography books as they are very well written.

Thoroughly enjoyed this book.I regularly listen to Paul O'Grady on Radio 2 on a Sunday afternoon and could hear him saying various things in his book. His humour matches mine exactly and he never fails to make me laugh.I laughed a lot whilst reading this book and cried at the end when Paul says about his parents' illness and the subsequent death of his father. He described how he felt to eloquently, that I remembered how I felt when my father died.A very good book. I can recommend it to anyone, so long as you don't mind some bad language and references to sex of various types.

I'm not a particular fan of Paul O'Grady the TV personality but I really warmed to him as a person after watching For the Love of Dogs. In this book he comes across as a naturally funny person and it made me laugh out loud in places. The closeness of his family was heart-warming and I particularly loved reading about his aunt Chrissie. He is very up-front about his sexuality without being crude and the descriptions of the gay bars was a real eye-opener. Biographies aren't my first choice of reading but I may well read some more of Paul O'Grady's.

Entertaining, funny and moving. A brilliant and witty knack for description. I like Paul O'Grady but wouldn't say I'm a big fan, yet this book would probably entertain anyone with even a hint of interest in him. I actually read the second autobiography first (The Devil Rides Out) when it was on offer and that's what prompted me to read more. That was great too but this first installment is even better.

Acutely observed and well written, I really enjoyed this. There are some laugh out load moments, and some episodes, that are very reminiscent of an early 60's Coronation Street script - The women that have heavily influenced Paul's life, literally jump off the page. Can't wait to read the other autobiographical volumes in the series.

LifeLife is remembered how one wants it ,you remember the great,good and sad üò¢ times we all want our memories to be good because life should be good, not dwelling on the sad times they just pull you down. The saying goes always look on the bright side of life. Good üëç and funny, feel as if Paul is in the room chatting with you.

An interesting book by an interesting fella - got me through two train journeys and a couple of classes babysitting A Level students here in China - Thank God for kindle on my phone. (I am pretty sure I've read this before - or maybe I read another of his books and some of the stories have been repeated)

'At My Mother's Knee...' struck a chord with me as I worked, briefly, in Liverpool in the 80s. Lots of O'Grady's family and friends were larger than life characters and being gay he frequented some interesting haunts. All in all, a humorous biography focusing on his early childhood and teenage years that merits 7 out of 10. I have an idea that the next in the series will pick up the pace...

Entertaining This is funny, honest and an interesting picture of life in the fifties and sixties. I love the stories about his mother and aunts and their forthright approach to life. His mother is a great character who could clearly read her son like a book, much to his chagrin!

Fabulous story, fabulously told, of the early years of Paul. I had no idea about his close shaves with the law, or his nocturnal adventures in the docks, via the whores‚Äô entrance! Looking forward to picking up the next instalment...

Interesting readI like how Paul tells a story, warts and all. I love his sense of humour and one liners. However, when it came to his Mam and Dad having their heart attacks, I cried my eyes out. Looking forward to reading more of his books

If you want a honest telling of Paul‚Äôs life this book tells you his youth, school, his family, church, being a dad, being gay and the drag artist I really enjoyed this never knew about his jobs before the stage A great man great story

Oh just love Paul O'Grady and really enjoyed this story of his life as a youngster! Full of heartwarming tales growing up in Birkenhead, so honest, insightful, funny, sad and there was the odd occasion where I had to say "Oh no!". Loved it!
Such an honest account of Paul O'Gradys childhood. With as typical with his books many laugh out loud moments.
This book is amazing! As a fan of both Lily and Paul! This book was a must and it didn‚Äôt fail

Excellent funny read reminded me of my childhood in Liverpool with blacklers and Owen owens
Very interesting read laughs here and there as well really enjoyed it as i have all his books.
Well written book.This book is the second I have read by Mr O,Grady, and have found both to be interesting and a pleasure to read.
Thoroughly enjoyed his book. Told with his usual wit, of his life growing up.
Great insight into the life that made him the showman he is
It's really good. Paul tells you all about his childhood. It is funny and sad. I enjoyed reading it.
Absolutely wonderful. Written with Paul‚Äôs unmistakable voice and wit, this is a must read memoir. It covers his childhood and teenage years and family life. Totally addictive and absorbing.
A really enjoyable book. So funny. So emotional.
Particularly enjoyed the first half of the book about his childhood. Very evocative of the time‚Äôs.
Very honest, funny and entertaining read
Brought back a lot of good memories from growing up in Liverpool, thoroughly enjoyed this
Fantastic! Engaging throughout, looking forward to reading the next installment.
Good read, funny, emotional, looking forward to the follow up
This book ended just as things were getting really interesting. I hope there‚Äôs a sequel
Emotional read can‚Äôt wait for next book
Very funny and entertaining tales of Paul O‚ÄôGrady‚Äôs family and his early life. You can hear him telling you the tales as you read.
Brilliantly writtenI just wanted it to keep on going, such a brilliantly written with laughter and tears. Cannot wait to start the next installmentüíñüíñüíñüíñüíñüëç

I‚Äôve read quite a few biographies and autobiographies , and even more than usual in the last two years. Paul O‚ÄôGrady‚Äôs is one of the best I‚Äôve read. He‚Äôs a really, really good writer. Funny, interesting, honest; he draws the characters really well. In the later chapters where he‚Äôs drinking and working in Liverpool bars I thought of Charles Bukowski for some reason, although it‚Äôs ages since I read any.

A very humorous book, I really enjoyed this and will definitely read more of Paul's Autobiographies. Covering Paul's life from birth to around 18 we learn about his family and neighbours, Paul's time at school, entering the world of work and also some adventures as he begins exploring the gay clubs where he lived. It's all very wittily written, but with real heart. I can definitely hear Paul's voice when reading this book and I think it gives readers a real insight into how he became the man he is. Incidentally, I have met Paul O'Grady in a work situation and he was charming - very polite, quietly spoken and keen to do what was required of his role at the event. When he went on stage his comedy persona came to the fore and he had his audience in stitches. A lovely man. Also very, very tall!

Bought this cause it was going cheap but turned out to be a nice read. All about his childhood and teenage years so interesting to understand where he came from and who and what shaped him and his stage characters. I always had the feeling though that he wasn't being totally honest with us when telling his story.
As you read it you hear Paul O'Grady speaking. A terrific book and well worth the read
could not fault this book in any way fantastic made me laugh and cry in equal amounts.
this is so funny in places just love how he writes
Funny, honest and touching.
Love Paul, love him even more after reading this.
i have to say i love all of his books!! they are so honest and hilarious!
What a joy to read, it was like you were chatting over a mug of tea & digestivesGreat read

Loved this from start to finish absolutely amazing man and what a life! You inspire me to just live life to the full!!
